metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Respondent Firm

facts.text: The respondent is a firm registered under section 26A of the Income-tax Act for assessment years 1958-59, 1959-60, and 1960-61.
Respondent earned income from property, ready business in kappas, and speculation business.

In assessment year 1958-59: income from property Rs. 1,369/-, from ready business Rs. 28,449/-, loss in speculation business Rs. 6,26,606/-. ITO charged tax on total income from property and ready business Rs. 29,818/-, did not set off speculation loss per first proviso to s. 24(1), but apportioned speculation loss between partners per second proviso to s. 24(1).

In assessment year 1959-60: income from property, loss in ready business exceeding property income, net loss Rs. 1,239/- apportioned between partners; speculation loss Rs. 5,416/- apportioned between partners.

In assessment year 1960-61: income from property Rs. 1,014/-, loss from ready business Rs. 21,197/-, profit from speculation business Rs. 6,19,784/-. First proviso to s. 24(1) did not apply due to speculation profit; net income computed including all heads.

Respondent claimed set off of speculation losses from 1958-59 and 1959-60 against 1960-61 speculation profit, arguing ITO wrongly apportioned losses under second proviso to s. 24(1), entitling carry forward under s. 24(2)(i).
ITO rejected claim; upheld by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal accepted respondent's plea, held speculation losses from prior years adjustable against 1960-61 speculation profit.

At Commissioner's request, Tribunal referred question to Gujarat High Court: Whether Tribunal correct in holding speculation losses of 1958-59 and 1959-60 set off against Rs. 6,19,784/- speculation profit in 1960-61.
Gujarat High Court upheld Tribunal, answered question in favour of respondent on September 13/16, 1963.
Commissioner obtained certificate under s. 66A(2) for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case and on a true interpretation of the various provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the Tribunal was correct in holding that speculation losses of the Respondent firm for the assessment years 1958-59 and 1959-60 should be set off against its speculation profit of Rs. 6,19,784/- in its assessment for the assessment year 1960-61.
Interpretation of the second proviso to s. 24(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, particularly whether speculation losses can be apportioned between partners of a registered firm.

petitioner_arguments.text: Speculation losses were correctly apportioned between partners under second proviso to s. 24(1) in 1958-59 and 1959-60, preventing carry forward and set off against 1960-61 speculation profits by the firm under s. 24(2).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Second proviso to s. 24(1); s. 24(2) proviso (c); first proviso to s. 23(5)(a)

respondent_arguments.text: ITO wrongly apportioned speculation losses between partners under second proviso to s. 24(1); such losses could not be apportioned, entitling firm to carry forward under s. 24(2)(i) and set off against 1960-61 speculation profits.

court_reasoning.text: Principal clause of s. 24(1) allows set off of losses under any head against income under other heads; first proviso excludes speculation losses except against other speculation profits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: ITO correctly did not set off speculation losses in 1958-59 and 1959-60.

court_reasoning.text: Second proviso to s. 24(1) deals with personality of assessee (firms), not computation of total income; 'any such loss' refers to losses computed under principal clause read with first proviso, excluding speculation losses.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Speculation losses not apportionable between partners of registered firm.

court_reasoning.text: Interpreting second proviso to include speculation losses would nullify first proviso.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Losses under second proviso exclude speculation losses.

court_reasoning.text: S. 24(2)(i) allows set off of speculation losses only against speculation profits; proviso (c) confirms registered firm can carry forward unapportioned speculation losses.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proviso (c) envisages unapportioned losses, which must be speculation losses.

court_reasoning.text: First proviso to s. 23(5)(a) does not apply to speculation losses excluded under s. 24(1) first proviso.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Speculation losses outside scope of s. 23(5)(a).

holdings.text: Second proviso to s. 24(1) does not permit apportionment of speculation losses between partners of registered firm; such losses remain with firm for carry forward and set off under s. 24(2) against future speculation profits.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs computation of total income, set off and carry forward of losses, especially speculation losses for registered firms; second proviso to s. 24(1) excludes speculation losses from apportionment.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Gujarat High Court and Tribunal, holding that speculation losses of prior years were not apportionable between partners and could be set off by the registered firm against 1960-61 speculation profits.
outcome.relief_granted: Set off of speculation losses from 1958-59 and 1959-60 against 1960-61 speculation profit allowed to respondent firm.

key_quotes.text: The language used in the second proviso, thus, itself leads to the conclusion that the decision arrived at by the High Court was correct, even though on a different reasoning.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms agreement with High Court's outcome on interpretation of s. 24(1) second proviso.

key_quotes.text: The only interpretation that can be placed on the words 'any such loss' in this part of the second proviso is that this expression refers to the loss as determined for purposes of the principal clause of s. 24(1) read with the first proviso, and, thus, does not comprise within it loss incurred in speculative business.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding excluding speculation losses from apportionment.
